author: ralexstokes
content: the first deployment of sharding will not have any execution -- so users of the shards will just post a sequence of bytes when they need to post data to some shard

author: ralexstokes
content: validators in the system propose shard blocks and other validators confirm those shard blocks are available

author: ralexstokes
content: if i know some data is available then i can do things like e.g. build a rollup on top of it

author: ralexstokes
content: so yeah you can imagine arbitrum, optimism, etc. will post L2 blocks as shard blobs which are confirmed by the L1 validators

author: ralexstokes
content: these L2 sequencers will follow the L1 consensus to know what has been confirmed (i.e. letting them compute the latest L2 state)

author: ralexstokes
content: details of the networking are still to be determined but any user of a shard should be able to get any data onto any particular shard and it won't really matter as long as that user can track which blobs are where

author: ralexstokes
content: e.g. arbitrum posts to shards 1, 2, 7, optimism posts to shards 4, 5, 6, dydx posts to shard 2 but just in a different part of the shard chain than arbitrum (note: users can even share a given shard block, they don't need to be in distinct shard blocks)

author: ralexstokes
content: there is no higher-level structure like a "transaction hash" or a "addresses" so you don't need to worry about sharding on those "keys"

author: ralexstokes
content: and bc there is no execution  we don't have to worry about the complexities of cross-shard execution (kind of the point to go for data sharding before execution sharding)

author: ralexstokes
content: so its better to think about the shards as just a uniform data layer that applications can use for availability

author: ralexstokes
content: there will be details/mechanics to resolve like which data gets into which shard at which block but at this point it is more just like "punctuation" that a user of the shards doesn't really need to worry about
